urn:contentItem:3Y5S-8GF0-00MP-T04H-00000-00Defying Breadth Again, Nasdaq Jumps Within 63 Points of 40001999-12-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:21ZLexisNexisMARKETS; Market RoundupDefying Breadth Again, Nasdaq Jumps Within 63 Points of 4000By Aaron L. Task, Senior WriterDecember 22, 1999 5:46 PM ET

SAN FRANCISCO -- As a wise man once sang: "Only fools rush in." 

Today, the smart investors were those who waited for the dip and then bought in anticipation of the rise, which inevitably came and led the Nasdaq Composite Index and S&P 500 deeper into record territory. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose as investors continued to heed the "all clear" sign given by the Federal Reserve, albeit with less enthusiasm than yesterday . 

Major IndicesINDEXCHANGE%VALUEYR TO DATEDow3.06+0.03%11,203.60+22%S&P 5002.56+0.2%1435.99+16.8%Nasdaq25.95+0.7%3937.10+79.6%Russell 20002.15+0.5%477.94+13.3%TSC Internet10.97-1%1148.10+183%TSC Red Hots4.78+1.1%422.33N/ABONDCHANGEPRICEYIELD30-Year Treasury6/3295 23/326.449%

 

Indeed, while investors can't help falling in love with certain tech stocks, there ardor was restrained today. Major averages all closed below intraday bests and traders reported the first noticeable signs of pre-holiday type action. 

"We're seeing some decent activity but it's quieting down after the feeding frenzy the last couple of weeks," said Jim Volk, co-director of institutional trading at D.A. Davidson in Portland, Ore. "I think it's been consistently busier because institutions are putting money to work. Every once in a while we see some profit-taking and a lot of big stocks are down today. But they're still buying telecom and B2B and tech, while a lot of other stuff goes begging." 

The market: Join the discussion on TSC Message Boards. 

In the profit-taking department, Volk mentioned Qualcomm (QCOM:Nasdaq), which closed off 2.3% at 485 7/16 after rising as high as 522 1/8 in the first five minutes of trading. (The stock was slumping hard after hours on disappointment with news of Qualcomm's sale of its handset business.) 

Among news-driven declines, Lucent (LU:NYSE), 3Com (COMS:NYSE) and Corel (CORL:Nasdaq) each suffered big drops. 

Lucent declined 3.6% to 76 5/8 after trading as low as 73 1/2. Some cautious comments by the firm in a 10-Q filing with the Securities & Exchange Commission prompted analysts at J.P. Morgan and Warburg Dillon Read to question Lucent's growth prospects. 

Meanwhile, 3Com lost 8.9% to 48 7/16 after trading as low as 43 5/8. Although its earnings bested expectations; the company also posted sluggish sales growth last night. Finally, Corel declined 29.3% after warning about a profit shortfall for the fourth-quarter. Corel's decline was exaggerated because the stock had risen sharply in previous weeks amid the excitement over anything related to the Linux operating system. 

After rising as high as 3948.48 in the opening moments of trading, the Nasdaq Comp's momentum waned through the rest of the morning. But after bottoming at 3878.06 shortly before lunchtime, the tech-bolstered index rallied back through most of the afternoon to finish up 25.95, or 0.7%, to 3937.10. The close is the Nasdaq's 28th record in the past 38 trading days. 

In addition to 3Com and Corel's losses, the Comp had to overcome weakness in bellwethers such as Cisco (CSCO:Nasdaq) and MCIWorldCom (WCOM:Nasdaq). Giving the index a lift were tech giants such as Oracle (ORCL:Nasdaq), Microsoft (MSFT:Nasdaq), and Yahoo! (YHOO:Nasdaq), as well as momentum favorites such as Internet Capital Group (ICGE:Nasdaq) and Commerce One (CMRC:Nasdaq). 

Reflecting the mixed tone within tech today, TheStreet.com Internet Sector index declined 10.97, or 1%, to 1148.10. TheStreet.com Red Hots index rose 4.78, or 1.1%, to 422.33. The 20-stock index tracks action in particularly volatile stocks and is meant to measure so-called hot money. (You can check quotes on the Red Hots index and its component stocks at http://www.thestreet.com/redhots.)

Meanwhile, the Dow closed up 3.06 to 11,203.60 after trading as high as 11,260.18 and as low as 11,181.89. 

The blue-chip proxy got a big lift from Eastman Kodak (EK:NYSE), which rose 8.2% after naming a new CFO. Additionally, Procter & Gamble (PG:NYSE) rose 4.3% to spur the Dow. 

The index was most restrained by American Express (AXP:NYSE), J.P. Morgan (JPM:NYSE) and Honeywell (HON:NYSE).
 
Recent Laggards Lift S&P 

Given the uncharacteristically uneven performance of big tech stocks, the S&P 500 turned to some recently punk names to help it secure its second-straight record. The index closed up 2.56, or 0.2%, to 1435.99 after trading as high as 1440.02 and as low as 1429.05. 

In addition to the aforementioned Dow components, the (previously) unsung heroes included Safeway (SWY:NYSE) and a slew of drug makers, including Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY:NYSE) and Pfizer (PFE:NYSE). The American Stock Exchange Pharmaceutical Index jumped 2.2%. 

Today's move comes amid talk by some market players that the yawning gap between the performance of growth and value stocks will begin to close. However, the S&P Barra Growth Index rose 0.3% to an all-time high of 876.6 today, continuing to outperform the S&P Barra Value Index, which dipped 0.1%. 

"There's been a really interesting dynamic at work in the market this last three, four weeks, which is that people have gotten a lot of positive reinforcement from investing in tech stocks," said Jon Olesky, head of block trading at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter . Tech has "turned out not to be the leadership, but the only aspect of the market that's working." 

Thus, the continued gains by growth stocks is not surprising, especially given investors' reluctance to incur capital gains before year-end or "give back" performance, he said. "A lot of this right now is very much related to the calendar." 

The Russell 2000 closed up 2.15, or 0.5%, to 477.94 despite another session of negative breadth. 

In New York Stock Exchange trading, 852.9 million shares were exchanged while declining stocks led advancers 1,692 to 1,417. In Nasdaq Stock Market action, 1.46 billion shares traded while losers led 2,254 to 1,914. New 52-week lows whipped new highs 312 to 80 on the Big Board while new highs led 278 to 150 in over-the-counter trading. 

Among other indices, Dow Jones Transportation Average rose 2.24, or 0.1%, to 2838.74; the Dow Jones Utility Average gained 0.32, or 0.1%, to 277.42; and the American Stock Exchange Composite Index added 4.79, or 0.6%, to 839.43. 

Elsewhere in North American equities, the Toronto Stock Exchange 300 gained 7.06 to 8257.1 and the Mexican Stock Exchange IPC Index dropped 126.46, or 1.8%, to 6850.29.
 
Wednesday's Company Report 

By Tara Murphy
Staff Reporter 

(Earnings estimates from First Call; new highs and lows on a closing basis unless otherwise specified. Earnings reported on a diluted basis unless otherwise specified.)
 
Mergers, acquisitions and joint ventures 

America Online (AOL:NYSE) fell 1 13/16 to 83 1/4 after it agreed to buy MapQuest.com (MQST:Nasdaq) for $1.1 billion in stock. MapQuest dropped 6 15/16 to 25 1/2 on the news. 

For more on the America Online/MapQuest deal, take a look at the story written by TheStreet.com/NYTimes.com joint newsroom. 

The European Commission said it gave regulatory approval to a takeover of CDnow (CDNW:Nasdaq) by Sony (SNE:NYSE ADR) and Time Warner (TWX:NYSE). CDnow subsequently will be merged with Time Warner and Sony's jointly held Columbia House. CDnow fell 7/8, or 7.3%, to 11 3/16, Sony soared 19 1/16, or 9%, to 230 3/8 and Time Warner popped 1 7/16 to 66 15/16. 

Comcast(CMCSK:Nasdaq) gained 1 5/16 to 52 3/16 after it said it had entered a stock deal to fully purchase Jones Intercable(JOINA:Nasdaq) for about $3.2 billion. Jones rose 3 3/16 to 70. Initially, Comcast said it would increase its interest in Jones to 79%. Comcast currently holds a 37% ownership stake and a 47% voting interest in Jones. The transaction sees Jones worth about $71.40 a share based on the closing price of Comcast's Class-A shares. 

Electronic Data Systems (EDS:NYSE) lifted 3 15/16, or 6.2%, to 67 9/16 after it said General Motors' (GM:NYSE) North American unit has renewed a three-year agreement for EDS to provide information technology systems and services to G.M.'s U.S., Canadian and Mexican operations. GM inched up 3/4 to 71 3/8. 

Genome (GENE:Nasdaq) jumped 4 1/4, or 46%, to 13 1/2 after it said it will team up with a unit of American Home Products (AHP:NYSE) on an osteoporosis drug. American Home fell 9/16 to 40. 

Separately, a Mississippi judge struck down a $150 million jury award, which was given to five former users of the "fen-phen" diet-drug combination, against American Home Products after the company settled "substantially all" of hundreds of other diet-drug lawsuits pending in the state. 

L-3 Communications (LLL:NYSE) lifted 4 3/8, or 11.3%, to 43 1/8 after it said it agreed to buy the Space and Navigations Systems weapons business of the former AlliedSignal, for $55 million in cash. Honeywell (HON:NYSE) merged with AlliedSignal and was required to sell the business as a condition of the deal. Shares of Honeywell fell 2 5/8 to 54 1/16. 

Merrill Lynch (MER:NYSE) fell 1/8 to 77 7/8 after it announced a multiyear partnership with Multex.com (MLTX:Nasdaq) to develop financial information Web sites for the U.S. brokerage. Multex moved up 8 3/16, or 27.7%, to 38 3/8. Merrill will also take an undisclosed stake in Multex, not to exceed 5% of its outstanding stock. 

For more on the Merrill Lynch/Multex deal, take a look at the story written by TheStreet.com/NYTimes.com joint newsroom. 

Tellabs (TLAB:Nasdaq) slipped 7/8 to 64 7/16 after saying it is acquiring closely held Salix Technologies, a provider of voice-over-Internet services, for about $300 million in stock
 
Earnings/revenue reports and previews 

Corel (CORL:Nasdaq) fell 5 7/16, or 29.3%, to 13 3/16 after saying it will post lower fourth-quarter revenue and a loss for the period. The company said it would report a loss of 14 cents a share, compared with earnings of 10 cents a year ago. The four-analyst estimate calls for earnings of 12 cents a share. Corel also said it acquired a one-third stake in LinuxForce of Philadelphia with a three-year option to increase the portion to two-thirds. 

For more on Corel, take a look at the story written by TheStreet.com/NYTimes.com joint newsroom. 

American-Swedish drugs group Pharmacia & Upjohn (PNU:NYSE) added 1 to 46 5/8 and Monsanto (MTC:NYSE) added 9/16 to 36 13/16 after the companies said they estimated earnings for 2000 would be between $1.55 and $1.62 per share if their planned merger went ahead. The companies said they expected annual EPS growth of more than 20% after 2000. 

Pharmacia and Upjohn also said it sees reasons to sell Monsanto's agricultural unit earlier than it originally said. 

3Com (COMS:Nasdaq) lost 4 3/4, or 8.9%, to 48 7/16 after last night reporting second-quarter earnings of 37 cents a share, beating the 26-analyst estimate of 34 cents and up from the year-ago 36 cents. Despite the solid earnings report, the stock was getting hit in Instinet trading , lately down 8 1/4 to 45 after its CFO said he expects third-quarter profits to be "comparable" with a year ago. 

Worthington Industries(WTHG:Nasdaq) moved up 1/16 to 15 7/16 after it posted second-quarter earnings of 28 cents a share, beating the seven-analyst estimate of 25 cents and the year-ago 24 cents.
 
Analyst actions 

Goldman Sachs lowered its 1999 earnings estimate on Bank One (ONE:NYSE) to $3.43 from $3.50 a share. The estimate for 2000 was lowered to $3.25 from $3.85. Shares of Bank One edged up 3/16 to 33 1/2. 

Credit Suisse First Boston raised its rating on Burlington Northern (BNI:NYSE) to buy from hold. Shares of Burlington Northern added 15/16 to 24 1/16. 

Merrill Lynch made Coca-Cola(KO:NYSE) its Focus 1 stock pick. Shares of Coca-Cola gained 1/16 to 58 1/2. 

First Boston raised its rating on Dynegy (DYN:NYSE) to buy from hold. Dynegy climbed 1 1/8, or 5.4%, to 21 15/16. 

First Albany division FAC Equities upped its rating on Cognos(COGN:Nasdaq) to buy from neutral. Merrill Lynch also raised its rating on the stock to a near-term buy from accumulate. Shares of Cognos lifted 5 7/8, or 15.4%, to 43 7/8. 

SG Cowen upped its price target on Cognizant Technology Solutions(CTSH:Nasdaq) to 150 from 50. Shares of Cognizant advanced 25 1/2, or 28.1%, to 117. 

SG Cowen upped its price target on Electronic Data Systems(EDS:NYSE) to 80 from 70. Shares of EDS rose 3 15/16, or 6.1%, to 67 9/16. 

Goldman Sachs started coverage of Dun & Bradstreet (DNB:NYSE) with a market outperform rating. Shares of Dun & Bradstreet lost 3/16 to 29 1/8. 

Banc of America Securities upped its rating on Gymboree (GYMB:Nasdaq) to market perform from underperform. Shares of Gymboree advanced 5/8, or 11.1%, to 6 3/8. 

Lehman Brothers sliced its fiscal 2000 earnings estimate on Keane (KEA:AMEX) to 90 cents from $1.05 a share. Shares of Keane slipped 2 5/8, or 7.5%, to 32 3/8. 

Warburg Dillon Read initiated coverage of Protein Design Labs(PDLI:Nasdaq) with a buy rating and a price target of 74. Protein Design Labs advanced 8 11/16, or 15.9%, to 63 1/8. 

Banc of America raised its rating on Verity (VRTY:Nasdaq) to buy from market perform. Shares of Verity edged up 6 13/16, or 22.6%, to 36 7/8.
 
Offering and stock actions 

Cablevision Systems (CVC:NYSE) bounced 1 11/16 to 77 1/4 after it said its board voted to create a new tracking stock to follow the activity of its entertainment unit, which includes cable television stations American Movie Classics and the MSG Network. 

For more on Cablevision, take a look at the story written by TheStreet.com/NYTimes.com joint newsroom. 

Federal Realty Investment Trust(FRT:NYSE) added 1/8 to 18 1/8 after it said it has set a repurchasing plan of up to four million shares, or about 10% of the company's stock. 

Nashua (NSH:NYSE) lifted 9/16, or 8.3%, to 7 5/16 after it said its board authorized the repurchase of up to one million shares. 

Network Solutions (NSOL:Nasdaq) gained 4 13/16 to 272 1/4 after it said it set a 2-for-1 stock split and it registered for the sale of 7.73 million common shares. The company said it was considering separating its registry and registrar services and that it had hired advisers to review its business structure. Network Solutions also said two of its board members resigned. 

PSEG (PEG:NYSE) tacked on 1/2 to 33 5/8 after said its board approved the repurchase of up to an additional 10 million shares of common stock. 

United Auto Group (UAG:NYSE) advanced 3/16 to 8 5/16 after it approved a share buyback of up to 10%.
 
Miscellany 

Boeing(BA:NYSE) said it has received an order for five Next Generation 737-800s and two 757-200s from GATX(GMT:NYSE) unitGATX Capital. 

The Federal Communications Commission approved Bell Atlantic's (BEL:NYSE) bid to offer long-distance phone service in New York, marking the first time since the break-up of AT&T in 1984, that a Baby Bell was allowed to offer distant calling services in its own region. Bell Atlantic said it would move quickly to garner long distance phone service customers and aims to have 1 million New York customers in 2000. Shares of Bell Atlantic slipped 1 1/16 to 64 1/2. 

AT&T (T:NYSE) said it expected to file a lawsuit challenging the FCC's decision. Shares of AT&T were losing 1 7/16 to 52 3/4. 

For more on Bell Atlantic, take a look at the story written by TheStreet.com/NYTimes.com joint newsroom. 

Eastman Kodak (EK:NYSE) jumped 4 11/16, or 8.1%, to 62 1/16 after it said it named Unisys (UIS:NYSE) executive Robert Brust as its new CFO to replace Harry Kavetas, who died in May. 

Ford(F:NYSE) gained 1/4 to 51 after it said it won the biggest electric vehicle order from the U.S. Postal Service to date. 

Harsco (HSC:NYSE) slid 9/16 to 29 3/8 after it said it would plead guilty and pay $11 million to settle a federal charge against its former BMY Combat Services Division. 

The SEC said it has censured and fined Scudder Kemper Investments and penalized two former employees involved in unauthorized derivatives trading that led investors losing more than $16 million in investors losses. The SEC found that Scudder and its derivatives trading supervisor failed to adequately monitor the trader and supervise controls and procedures. 

Scudder said it would agree to be censured and pay a fine of $250,000, while its former Boston derivatives head, Gary Paul Johnson, would take a one-year suspension and pay a $10,000 fine. The trader involved, Michael Sullivan III, is barred from the industry for five years. 

The Treasury Department sold $15 billion of two-year notes today at a high yield of 6.233%, the department announced. This is the last auction of the year for the Treasury. 

Because the two-year notes sold between a yield of 6.125% and 6.249%, it was designated a reopening of the five-year note sale from Dec. 31, 1996. The $15 billion in notes were sold at a yield of 6.233%, with a coupon of 6.125%. The bid-to-cover ratio, which measures the total number of bids against what was offered, was 2.10, which means interest for the auction wasn't as low as expected. 

The Heard on the Street column in The Wall Street Journal took a look at the stock of Juno Online (JWEB:Nasdaq), which jumped more than four times in value after the company announced Monday that it will provide full Internet access at no charge, while also increasing its advertising spending. Investors easily looked past the fact that the new plan will cause the company's losses to widen. Also see yesterday's story from TheStreet.com on Juno's jumping stock. Shares of Juno Online slipped 5 3/16, or 7.7%, to 61 1/4.

urn:contentItem:600W-C821-DXY4-X03R-00000-00Defying Trump, Twitter Doubles Down on Labeling Tweets2020-05-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:21ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYDefying Trump, Twitter Doubles Down on Labeling TweetsKate Conger and Mike Isaac

Twitter continued fact-checking posts even as President Trump threatened to limit protections for social media companies.

Twitter continued fact-checking posts even as President Trump threatened to limit protections for social media companies.

OAKLAND, Calif. — Twitter continued to add new fact-checking labels to hundreds of tweets, even as the Trump administration issued an executive order to curtail the legal protections that shield social media companies from liability for the content posted on their platforms.

Twitter’s move escalated the confrontation between the company and President Trump, who has fulminated this week over actions taken by his favorite social media service.

Twitter on Tuesday had appended fact-checking labels for the first time to two of Mr. Trump’s tweets about mail-in ballots, rebutting their accuracy. In response, Mr. Trump accused Twitter of stifling speech and declared that he would put a stop to the interference.

On Thursday, Mr. Trump signed an executive order to make it easier for federal regulators to argue that companies like Facebook, Google and Twitter were suppressing free speech when they suspended users or deleted posts. The tech companies have had “unchecked power to censor, restrict, edit, shape, hide, alter any form of communication between private citizens or large public audiences,” he said.

But Twitter has doubled down. Late Wednesday, it added fact-checking labels to messages from Zhao Lijian, a spokesman for China’s foreign ministry who had claimed that the coronavirus outbreak may have begun in the United States and been brought to China by the U.S. military.

Twitter also added notices on hundreds of tweets that falsely claimed a photo of a man in a red baseball cap was Derek Chauvin, an officer involved in the death of George Floyd, an African-American man who died this week after being handcuffed and pinned to the ground by police. The Twitter label alerted viewers that the image was “manipulated media.”

The skirmish between Twitter and Mr. Trump shows that a backlash against large tech companies, which had receded in the initial phases of the pandemic, is now back in full force. The Justice Department has also recently signaled that it is preparing to bring an antitrust case against Google, perhaps as soon as this summer.

The executive order “seems designed to punish a handful of companies for perceived slights,” said Jon Berroya, chief executive of the Internet Association, a lobbying group representing many of the major tech companies. “It stands to undermine a variety of government efforts to protect public safety and spread critical information online through social media and threatens the vibrancy of a core segment of our economy.”

A Twitter spokeswoman said that the tweets modified on Wednesday contained “potentially misleading content” and that the fact-checking was consistent with the company’s approach this month.

In a series of tweets on Wednesday, Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief executive, also said he would not back down from the fact-checking effort. “We’ll continue to point out incorrect or disputed information,” he wrote.

The executive order aims at protections granted to technology services under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The law gives tech companies such as Facebook, Google and Twitter broad immunity from liability for content created by their users.

As Mr. Trump and other conservative figures have claimed that social media companies are biased against them, Republican lawmakers have proposed modifications to the statute. Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri has argued that to maintain Section 230 protections, social media services should be required to submit to a third-party audit to ensure their content moderation systems are politically neutral.

Senator Ron Wyden, a Democrat from Oregon who wrote the law, said Mr. Trump was threatening Section 230 to “chill speech and bully” the big tech companies into giving the White House more favorable treatment.

“He’s clearly targeting Section 230 because it protects private businesses’ right not to have to play host to his lies,” Mr. Wyden said in a statement. “Efforts to erode Section 230 will only make online content more likely to be false and dangerous.”

The executive order is likely to face legal challenges.

Harold Feld, the senior vice president of Public Knowledge, a policy nonprofit group, said the order appeared to be intended to limit speech on social media that disagreed with the president. That was “literally the worst case scenario that the authors of the First Amendment were afraid of,” he said.

Twitter’s confrontation with Mr. Trump has also opened new fissures in Silicon Valley. Mr. Dorsey has doubled down on fact-checking tweets, but Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, has distanced his social network from that effort.

“I just believe strongly that Facebook shouldn’t be the arbiter of truth of everything that people say online,” Mr. Zuckerberg said in a taped television interview that ran Thursday morning on Fox News.

His comments were at odds with some of his own company’s actions. In the past, Facebook, too, introduced fact-checking labels, using third-party services to review potentially false information. The approach has been scattershot and uneven, and critics have argued that third-party fact checkers have been unable to keep up with the billions of pieces of content on the social network.

Facebook has also said it would not allow posts that facilitated voter fraud or misinformation intended specifically to suppress voting.

“We’re talking about this as if it’s about fact-checking, but it’s not,” said Angelo Carusone, president of Media Matters for America, a left-leaning media watchdog. “It’s about whether platforms will facilitate fraud that undermines civic engagement.”

In a statement, Facebook said it opposed modifying Section 230 because that would “restrict more speech online, not less.”

On Twitter, Mr. Dorsey fired back after Mr. Zuckerberg’s comments became public before they were aired.

“This does not make us an ‘arbiter of truth,’” he said of his decision to fact-check tweets. “Our intention is to connect the dots of conflicting statements and show the information in dispute so people can judge for themselves.”

Kate Conger reported from Oakland, Calif., and Mike Isaac from San Francisco.

PHOTOS: Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco. The company added fact-checking labels to President Trump’s tweets for the first time on Tuesday. (PHOTOGRAPH BY JASON HENRY FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES); Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, has resisted fact checks. (PHOTOGRAPH BY PETE MAROVICH FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES) (B5)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:6014-0NF1-DYR7-C0N4-00000-00Defying Trump, Twitter Doubles Down on Labeling Tweets2020-05-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:21ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYDefying Trump, Twitter Doubles Down on Labeling TweetsKate Conger and Mike IsaacABSTRACT

Twitter continued fact-checking posts even as President Trump threatened to limit protections for social media companies.

FULL TEXT

May 28,2020, Thursday Online Correction:

This article has been revised to reflect the following correction: An earlier version of this article incorrectly referred to the day Twitter added additional labels to tweets. It was Wednesday, not Thursday.

CORRECTION APPENDED

Twitter continued fact-checking posts even as President Trump threatened to limit protections for social media companies.

OAKLAND, Calif. - Twitter continued to add new fact-checking labels to hundreds of tweets, even as the Trump administration issued an executive order to curtail the legal protections that shield social media companies from liability for the content posted on their platforms.

Twitter's move escalated the confrontation between the company and President Trump, who has fulminated this week over actions taken by his favorite social media service.

Twitter on Tuesday had appended fact-checking labels for the first time to two of Mr. Trump's tweets about mail-in ballots, rebutting their accuracy. In response, Mr. Trump accused Twitter of stifling speech and declared that he would put a stop to the interference.

On Thursday, Mr. Trump signed an executive order to make it easier for federal regulators to argue that companies like Facebook, Google and Twitter were suppressing free speech when they suspended users or deleted posts. The tech companies have had "unchecked power to censor, restrict, edit, shape, hide, alter any form of communication between private citizens or large public audiences," he said.

But Twitter has doubled down. Late Wednesday, it added fact-checking labels to messages from Zhao Lijian, a spokesman for China's foreign ministry who had claimed that the coronavirus outbreak may have begun in the United States and been brought to China by the U.S. military.

Twitter also added notices on hundreds of tweets that falsely claimed a photo of a man in a red baseball cap was Derek Chauvin, an officer involved in the death of George Floyd, an African-American man who died this week after being handcuffed and pinned to the ground by police. The Twitter label alerted viewers that the image was "manipulated media."

The skirmish between Twitter and Mr. Trump shows that a backlash against large tech companies, which had receded in the initial phases of the pandemic, is now back in full force. The Justice Department has also recently signaled that it is preparing to bring an antitrust case against Google, perhaps as soon as this summer.

The executive order "seems designed to punish a handful of companies for perceived slights," said Jon Berroya, chief executive of the Internet Association, a lobbying group representing many of the major tech companies. "It stands to undermine a variety of government efforts to protect public safety and spread critical information online through social media and threatens the vibrancy of a core segment of our economy."

A Twitter spokeswoman said that the tweets modified on Wednesday contained "potentially misleading content" and that the fact-checking was consistent with the company's approach this month.

In a series of tweets on Wednesday, Jack Dorsey, Twitter's chief executive, also said he would not back down from the fact-checking effort. "We'll continue to point out incorrect or disputed information," he wrote.

The executive order aims at protections granted to technology services under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The law gives tech companies such as Facebook, Google and Twitter broad immunity from liability for content created by their users.

As Mr. Trump and other conservative figures have claimed that social media companies are biased against them, Republican lawmakers have proposed modifications to the statute. Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri has argued that to maintain Section 230 protections, social media services should be required to submit to a third-party audit to ensure their content moderation systems are politically neutral.

Senator Ron Wyden, a Democrat from Oregon who wrote the law, said Mr. Trump was threatening Section 230 to "chill speech and bully" the big tech companies into giving the White House more favorable treatment.

"He's clearly targeting Section 230 because it protects private businesses' right not to have to play host to his lies," Mr. Wyden said in a statement. "Efforts to erode Section 230 will only make online content more likely to be false and dangerous."

The executive order is likely to face legal challenges.

Harold Feld, the senior vice president of Public Knowledge, a policy nonprofit group, said the order appeared to be intended to limit speech on social media that disagreed with the president. That was "literally the worst case scenario that the authors of the First Amendment were afraid of," he said.

Twitter's confrontation with Mr. Trump has also opened new fissures in Silicon Valley. Mr. Dorsey has doubled down on fact-checking tweets, but Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's chief executive, has distanced his social network from that effort.

"I just believe strongly that Facebook shouldn't be the arbiter of truth of everything that people say online," Mr. Zuckerberg said in a taped television interview that ran Thursday morning on Fox News.

His comments were at odds with some of his own company's actions. In the past, Facebook, too, introduced fact-checking labels, using third-party services to review potentially false information. The approach has been scattershot and uneven, and critics have argued that third-party fact checkers have been unable to keep up with the billions of pieces of content on the social network.

Facebook has also said it would not allow posts that facilitated voter fraud or misinformation intended specifically to suppress voting.

"We're talking about this as if it's about fact-checking, but it's not," said Angelo Carusone, president of Media Matters for America, a left-leaning media watchdog. "It's about whether platforms will facilitate fraud that undermines civic engagement."

In a statement, Facebook said it opposed modifying Section 230 because that would "restrict more speech online, not less."

On Twitter, Mr. Dorsey fired back after Mr. Zuckerberg's comments became public before they were aired.

"This does not make us an 'arbiter of truth,'" he said of his decision to fact-check tweets. "Our intention is to connect the dots of conflicting statements and show the information in dispute so people can judge for themselves."

Kate Conger reported from Oakland, Calif., and Mike Isaac from San Francisco.
